original_title: IMF welcomes Sri Lanka progress in policy actions, obtaining creditor assurances
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – The International Monetary Fund (IMF) welcomes the progress made by Sri Lanka in “decisive” policy actions and in obtaining financing assurances from all major creditors, IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva said.

Georgieva tweeted Tuesday March 07 night Sri Lanka time that the IMF looks forward to presenting what will be the island nation’s 17th IMF programme to the international lender’s executive board on March 20.

“The Extended Fund Facility (EFF) will support the authorities’ program of ambitious reforms, which will help Sri Lanka emerge from its current crisis and set it on a trajectory of strong and inclusive growth,” she said.

I welcome the progress made by 🇱🇰 Sri Lankan authorities in taking decisive policy actions & obtaining financing assurances from all their major creditors, incl. China, India & the Paris Club. Look forward to presenting the IMF-supported program to our Exec. Board on March 20.
Approval by the Board would also catalyze financing from other creditors, including the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank.

Sri Lanka is going to the IMF for the 17th time. The island suffered currency crises and output shocks after a soft-pegged central bank was set up in 1950 allowing the agency to engage in both exchange rate and monetary policy (printing money to suppress rates).

A new monetary law draft brings back exchange rate policy (which was dropped in the last reform as open market operations were started in the 1990s) and also output gap targeting. (Colombo/Mar07/2023)
